title: What is your least favorite word? - Quora
tags: Words and Phrases by Specific Language

response.answer_text: “Fluffy”. I bloody hate that word, I really do. Nothing that’s any good is ever fluffy. Is your smartphone fluffy? No it isn’t. Is your car fluffy? It wouldn’t go anywhere if it was. Nobody lives in a house with fluffy walls, which you enter through a fluffy door, and switch on your fluffy telly. I’ll tell you one thing that’s fluffy, and it’s a bloody pink horse (or it might be a unicorn, I’ve never got near enough to find out) that my neice (10) has got. It’s fluffy, it’s pink and it sings. Incessantly. I really hate that toy. One day, whatever is providing the sound is going to suffer an irreversible breakdown, due to a short circuit. If I can get it in the close proximity of me and a metal screwdriver and not in the close proximity of my niece. But that still won’t solve the awful problem of the pink fluffiness. I don’t think I’ll get away with sneaking out the back with it and a flamethrower and so daily I am accosted by this product from Satan Ltd. Toilet roll covers. They’re always fluffy. Why do we need to cover toilet rolls? “It looks nice”. No it does not. It looks as though we are some sort of discriminating bigots, denying the rolls their intrinsic cylindrical shape and forcing them to conform to our aesthetic and cultural standards, that’s what it looks like. Fairground gonks are fluffy. Frankly they give me the creeps with their mental, staring eyes. I can’t sleep if there’s a fluffy gonk in the house because I have this vague and uneasy suspicion that I’m going to wake up in the morning and find it’s come alive and is trying to asphyxiate me by cramming its fluffy mass down my respiratory tract. Don’t even get me started about candy floss. Cushions and pillows are often said to be fluffy. They may be on the inside but they have the decency to hide the fluffiness under a cotton skin. Cushions and pillows are therefore a force of good for the world. Or at least your butt-cheeks. Fluffy. Pah. Sod off fluffy, and whilst you’re going, take “frilly” with you.

Analytics. Over time, I have come to dislike this term. It is especially troubling in an environment that has been converted into a data-driven culture that is headed by those who think that they know how to interpret information when, in fact, they are comparing apples to oranges. It is with analytics and the other conflated terms associated that vital daily operations have become burdened with added bead counting tasks, as if they will make some genie appear from out of the mounds of added data. Too many places have joined the bandwagon of using statistics for virtually every facet that involves employees. What is the consequent of this mindset? Excessive micromanagement, where priorities can be so mishandled that the leading group’s dictates essentially amounting to the figurative tail wagging the dog. So one could argue that in the wrong hands, which is all too common, analytics can lead to decisions where outliers, which can be either detrimental or beneficial, or essentially the make-or-break points, are ignored. Once again, the baby can still be thrown out with the bath water. In other words, under certain circumstances, which are not few in number, it is just as indifference is regarded as the true opposite of love, it is to the same extent that analytics is the antithesis of logistics.

Snowflake. Even before I was old enough to understand or participate in sociopolitical discussions, I recognized snowflake as an insult for someone who is different, has different needs, or appreciates themselves as an individual seperate from a group. It's always annoyed me… such a vulgar energy for such a beautiful imagery.  Snowflakes are all unique. That's the point of the insult. When you call someone a snowflake, you're calling them different. Unique. Special. Individual. Irreplaceable. Precious. This is to say one of two things: “You're not special,” or, “You're special, and that's bad,” or sometimes, weirdly, both. But that's all irrelevant. People are just like snowflakes. We all are unique. We literally are. Even when we're twins, we're unique. You literally can't be the same as someone else. All people are snowflakes. There is no moral value on being an individual. Everybody just is. Embracing that is healthy. Insulting it is just sad. Yes, I believe in community. I believe in teamwork, cohesivity, and collectivism. I believe that being part of a whole is beautiful. But that isn't the same as being identical to other people. Just like snowflakes band together to create a snowbank, individuals band together to make a community. Together or not, we are all unique. And we can all be unique together.

I have a least favourite word, and I am going to add my least favourite phrase if I may. My least favourite word is 'ego'.  I cannot even tell you why I dislike it so.  I think it must be psychological - after all it is a word borne from a psychoanalytical theory first identified by Freud.  He maintains the ego stops us doing things that are socially unacceptable, and allows us to see other measures that would be better suited in the event of an incident.  This can only be a good thing.  However, whenever I hear the word ego it seems to be always used in the wrong context i.e.  'His ego is bigger than his boots'.  'If her ego gets any bigger, she will not be able to get through the door'.   My least favourite words strung together are: 'with all due respect...'  if someone starts a sentence to me with these words the hairs on my neck gradually rise.  Someone once wrote it to me on a comment box to my question here and I was mortified.  It shows a lack of respect and arrogance.  And in my opinion it means that there ego is too big!

“Closure.” Aside from the fact that there were words in the language that meant pretty much the same thing before someone invented this abomination, people (mis)use it as an excuse for all sorts of nastiness. People engage in horrible behavior, and claim they needed it for “closure,” as though it’s some kind of a Get out of Jail Free card. I’ve even heard it used in defense of the Death Penalty— it’s necessary to bring “closure” to victims’ families (and I’ll add that I had a family member murdered, and it wouldn’t help me, but nevermind), as though that is the last word on the matter. Closure is some how the be-all and end-all of everything. It’s enshrined and all-important. Well, it’s not; even if it were as achievable as the word makes it seem, it wouldn’t be the most important thing in the world.

Required. Why, you may ask? Because if something is required, it is entirely possible it is unneccessary. Not enough people are taking an optional customer service class for a job because they don't come into contact with customers and just work behind a desk? Boom! The class is now required, and you're forced to learn something you'll never use. I'm in high school, and yes, that's where this hatred of required comes from, but bear in mind, it's not over learning a language, or even taking PE. It's taking a computer programming class where it takes 1/2 an hour to complete something on the board I could do in 10 minutes. I never need to know how to build a car online. But here I am, in school, building a car online. I hate it. And nothing will change my opinion. I'd rather be in an art class.

One of my least favorite words lately is “awesome”. At least the way it is currently being used. Someone asks for directions to a restaurant. You tell them and they say “awesome”. I’ve had the good fortune to travel some and I’ve seen some awesome things, such as the Northern Lights, and actually got to play in the Pacific Ocean with some dolphins, and saw a volcano erupt (from 100 miles away). Those experiences were awesome. A bus coming by a given corner every 15 minutes is routine, not awesome.

Hi! Recently I am not liking the word transparent. For some reason (humm, I wonder why), we hear it more and more in the news and even commercial advertisements. I recently heard an automobile ad stating that the dealership is now more transparent than ever. How can something become more transparent? Isn’t transparent just transparent enough? So, in summary, I just don’t like this word. I feel that if someone needs to say they are transparent, then it’s a red flag that we can see through them to the real truth. I don’t mean to be negative—-just cautious. It’s tough for anyone or anything to really be 100% transparent! Funny word!

Anyone who uses this word, deserves life in prison. Here goes, I don't even like typing this word. My least favourite word is m…m….m…moi. Wow this is harder than I thought. Come on Gary just type it. MOIST. Ahhhhhh I should have just skipped this question. I don't know if this is an English thing for young people to use this word. But I hear so many people say it. Seriously if you are one of those people… stop!! This word is officially banned.

I really hate the word “problematic.” It has come to be a way for people to talk down to others. “I find your behavior problematic.” “Don’t you think their ideas are problematic.” I feel like you have to be really full of yourself to use this word. Second least favorite is “Flyover” as a way to describe the entire USA, that is not NYC or Los Angeles. I have actually lived in those cities, but now I live in Columbus Ohio, and hearing it makes my skin crawl. It is a way to dismiss the needs or ideas of anyone who isn’t them. Both these words are pretentious to the core!!!!

‘Not possible’ is one of the least favorite word I just hate the word’Not possible’.i feel a deep negative sense while people telling not possible while asking something,while doing something .i feel that we can change the decision said by the word ‘No’ but ‘Not possible’ is more strong and confident that we cannot change ,there is no second question or request for it. for example College days: Me:Mam,i got very less marks that is 12 , please make it as 15 Teacher:Not possible Interview: Interviewer:Sorry you are not selected better luck next time Me:Sir please give a second chance Interviewer:Not possible Office: Me:Shall i take 3 days leave? Manager:Not possible

Chav I hate this word because it is used to demonise the working class by the upper classes. If you are a teenager you are a Chav Anyone wearing a tracksuit is a Chav Anyone wearing a baseball cap tilted is a Chav Anyone unable to work is a Chav Anyone on minimum wage are a Chav I'm not a fan of words that demonise a whole section of society, it's completely unfair. E/D

WHATEVER. I really despise that word. Whoever use it to either end a conversation or shows a childish type of disagreement or lack of ability in communicating their needs really brings my blood to a boiling point. And I’m always calm and collected-or so I have told. But this one particular word really makes me want to turn into SHE-HULK.

The word “hot” Now before you try to tell me that hot is just a word to describe the high temperature, I don’t mean it as that way. The word “hot” I mean here is to describe about someone’s beauty. I feel really angry if someone call me hot. I’m mean, you can use a lot of words instead of hot to describe beauty like beautiful, pretty, good etc. Just don’t use the word “hot” because to me, that word sound like you want to do something with them for some reason. Anyway, that is just my opinion.

4 letter word. HATE  In sense, it has no meaning in literal sense. It provokes unnecessary feels. It's useless feeling. One needs to better understand the fact than develop a feeling for it. “Be that feeling, Love or Hate, Opinions or Feelings, unless it's properly understood, it doesn't make sense.” It will help a lot to understand one own self too. Happy Smiles! :) Govi!

“mentee” Stupid bloody word. Somebody latched onto the idea of agent nouns: that person who does a thing is a thing-er or a thing-or, and then that a person to whom (or for whom) that thing is done is a thing-ee … and then tried to apply that logic to “mentor”. Only “mentor” isn’t derived that way; there is no “ment” verb. It’s a guy’s name, from Greek mythology (wise counsellor/friend of Ulysses). So you might as well do the same thing with Stentor and say that a stentee is someone who gets shouted at.

“Triggered”,“SJW”. Seems like these days, every time you disagree with someone who’s political views are further right than your typical Democrat, you’re automatically “triggered” or an “SJW”. You also get accused by them of trying to stifle their free speech, which is ironic since free speech also means you have the right to disagree with them.

"Crave" or "craving". That one is really annoying. What's worse is when people truncate two words to make it one, like an old Taco Bell commercial where a guy said he was having "linner" (lunch + dinner).

Amazing. This meme is amazing. The movie was amazing. The food was amazing. You’ll be amazed when you see this post. She did an amazing job. I wish there was a word-filter on Facebook to remove this empty qualifier. As everything in the world is now amazing, the word means nothing.

Fax. Why do people bring up the name of a type of machine whenever they hear something that is true? I get that it is a corrupted version of “Facts”, but, why would you say “Facts” instead of “Right”, or “That’s true”, or even “Factual”? Come on, modern culture! At least use the correct modification of the word to agree with the sentence!

The four letter word that starts with S and ends at T. Yes, you guessed it right!! I don't like people saying it all the time when you can easily replace it with words like shoot, shucks, fish, damn and many more. Holy shit! I blew it.

Dyscalculia. It combines four flaws, which together make me hate it. It yokes a Greek prefix to a Latin root - no objection to that in itself, but see point 4.The Latin root is given a mangled pronunciation.The normal English pronunciation of “calcul-” is faithful to its source.“Dysarithmia” would have worked perfectly as a word to complement “dyslexia”.

I really hate the word “nice” and go out of my way to avoid using it. The word is incredibly bland and insipid. In my mind it’s lazy to use this word. When I hear it I want to scream “English is such a rich language, and yet you choose to use the word ‘nice’?!”
The subjective and changeful adjective "cool", especially to describe an object, person, or activities annoyed me quite a bit! I hated it, because I'm just not cool, at all!!

Bromance Why the fuck cant we just be friends? Pals? Buddies? Amigos? Why do women have to gay up everything men do? (There is nothing wrong with being gay if you actually are gay,but keep your hands off my dictionary,dont demasculinize everything)
Madam is one I can't stand, I will not address anyone as madam and really dislike being called it.

I know it is a natural bodily function, and no matter who a person is, everybody has them. But I seriously hate the word “booger”. I hate it, and I hate saying it aloud. Whenever I refer to it, I just point and show, not talk.
I don’t like the word “leery.” It doesn’t scare me, but despite its fairly long presence in the language, it sounds to me like misconceived slang that shouldn’t be in the dictionary.
What is your least favorite word? “Disrespect” when used as a verb. What’s wrong with plain old-fashioned ‘being rude to’ someone?
Schadenfreude,satisfaction or pleasure felt at someone else's misfortune. Origin of schadenfreude. 1890-1895. 1890-95; A loan word in English from German.A very sad word .
